Aircraft make loud sonic booms when they fly faster than the speed of sound.
That thunderclap is one of the main reasons supersonic planes aren't used commercially today.
Now NASA is building a test plane to evaluate ways to reduce that boom.
The supersonic test plane doesn't look all that different from a more conventional plane except for a long, pointy nose.
Supersonic aircraft tend to be long and slender anyway.
Low-boom supersonic aircraft is that to an extreme.
Peter Coen manages NASA's Commercial Supersonic Technology Project.
When he says low boom, Coen means low sonic boom.
So instead of a bang, you just hear a thump.
